product_name: SteelSeries Sensei Wireless Laser Gaming Mouse
summary: Nice mouse but one thing bothers me
reviewText: I've been using this mouse for awhile and unlike other people who have reviewed this mouse I am going to compare it to the G500, not the G700.The Sensei is a solid mouse but lacks the weight options of the G500. In fact while I used the G500 I added as much weight as I could and was used to how it moved. Switching to the Sensei took a little bit of getting used to but after a couple days it felt good.I like that it's wireless compared to the G500, and if you forget to cradle the Sensei to charge it, or have an extremely long play session unhooking the cord from the base and into the mouse makes it a wired option which is very nice for forgetful people like me.With software that you download from the SteelSeries website all the buttons are fully programmable, in fact you can program the buttons for different games and switch between those presets as you switch games which is also a very nice touch.Why the 4 Star rating then if I have nothing but good things to say you may be asking. Simple, do a lot of video editing and as such use the mouse extensively. The problem I have with this one is where the "forward" button is located and how low of profile it has. It makes it difficult to feel where it is, much less consistently press it when needed.It has a myriad of color options available for customization via the software. It's nice but really only useful for helping to monitor battery life.Overall I really like this mouse, it would be near perfect if those side buttons had a slightly different layout and a higher profile. As it is right now I can only say it's a very good option.

description: Final Fantasy Xis the first title in this landmark RPG series to be released for the PlayStation2. The main characters are Tidus, a star of blitzball (a hugely popular sport in the Final Fantasy universe), and Yuna, who has learned the art of summoning and controlling aeons, powerful spirits of yore. These two people of different backgrounds must work together as they journey through the world of Spira. This installment of Final Fantasy has a distinctly Asian influence, bringing a fresh feel to the characters, music, settings, and story.Features include voice-overs for the first time in the series (utilizing the Facial Motion System), high-polygon, motion-captured player characters designed by Tetsuya Nomura, and a camera that automatically adjusts its perspective to correspond with the movements of the characters--a feature now possible because the game is largely polygonal.
reviewText: Final Fantasy X is another great entry in the final fantasy series. The game follows Tidus as he tries to connect mysteries, falls in love, and realizes what he and his companions must do to save the world of Spira. From my opinion Final Fantasy X is the last great game in the final fantasy series, because after the creator Hironobu Sakaguchi left Square Enix the final fantasy games don't feel great anymore. Unless if he goes back one day. But yeah Final Fantasy X has great graphics, story, sound, and gameplay. You should play this game. You might be touched at the end of the game like some other people were.

description: Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliancetook co-operative action role-playing to new heights on the Playstation 2 console. Alone, or with a friend, you could tackle giant rats, undead monsters, dark elves, and even a white dragon, as you uncovered a plot against the good city of Baldur's Gate. But the ending indicated there was more adventure to come. Fans were worried that the sequel wouldn't live up to original's promise when the original design team jumped ship to work on Sony'sChampions of Norrath: Realms of EverQuest. They need not have worried;Dark Alliance 2is a worthy successor, retaining the weapons, monsters, Dungeons and Dragons action and rules, sharp graphics, responsive controls, and high adventure of its predecessor.The plot is a bit darker this time, but you're given a wider range of character classes to help face the elevated threats. There's the mighty barbarian, a dwarf rogue, a cleric, the monk (a martial artist), and a necromancer. The quest is huge and there are character-class specific side quests you can embark on--an extra incentive to play again as a different character. The level design tends to be a little too maze-like, and there's lots of boring backtracking, but the annoying jumping puzzles from the first game are gone.The biggest problem withDark Alliance 2is that it doesn't measure up to the competition. It's a 2-player game, whileDungeons & Dragons Heroes(on the Xbox) andChampions of Norrath(on the PS2 and Xbox) allow four-player play. Then again if you plan to play solo, or with a single friend, that shouldn't keep you from coming to the city ofBaldur's Gate'said once again.--Andrew Bub
reviewText: I liked them both but I enjoyed this more than the original. The first game has better atmosphere and voice acting. This one has better gameplay.  A worthy sequel.

summary: Frustrating fun or a fun frustration?
reviewText: A pair of games that came out for the Playstation 2 were the 2 "God of War" games which had some stellar production values, fun combat and varied combos and cool premise but frequently I felt it was hampered by vague puzzles or frustrating ones to pull off (the underwater wall puzzle you have to outrun, anyone?) and trying to afford the expensive power-ups by building up combos only to have enemies respawn AFTER your combo meter reset and went back to zero was maddening. That's when I noticed when a developer can become a game creator who's a fan or just a fan lucky to make games since decisions and gameplay ideas are introduced that might not work and can cause tedium but they're put in because they're "cool".However, a game's faults can be forgiven if it's actually fun to play and you almost excuse it because it does so many things well and Star Wars: The Force Unleashed, possibly the biggest console release for the series since the Knights of the Old Republic games, this is a game that will frequently have you wowed and having fun on one hand but then have you swearing and wanting to punch something on the other. It's definately worth a try and many forgive the flaws and go straight to purchase while others might just get annoyed by something very frequently. Doesn't mean there isn't a good time to be had here, it's just the game finds it hard to maintain that pace.Story: Taking place inbetween "Revenge of the Sith" and "A New Hope", the game starts off with Darth Vader on a planet causing devastation and ready to wipe out a Jedi in the vicinity. But when he also finds a young boy, Vader decides to take him under his wing and teach him privately. Now a young man, codenamed "Starkiller", he finds himself a Sith Apprentice but finds being on the side of evil doesn't mean your safety or life is highly valued and with the help of the robot PROXY and pilot Juno Eclipse, he's got to help the resistance with their plans against the Empire.Ironically, what people consider the best entry in the 2 film trilogies were the darker ones, "Empire Strikes Back" and "Revenge of the Sith". The tone for this game is similar and while it's not filled with big plot-twists like Knights first game, it's a very compelling and enjoyable story that you want to get to the end for and not just because you just want to get to the end of the game and move on to something else. Also what helps is the voice acting from Sam Witwer (the poor dude knifed in The Mist) as Starkiller to Nathalie Cox as Juno to Adrienne Wilkinson as Sith character Maris Brood. Having some characters from both the prequels and original trilogy show up make it awesome as well.Graphics: One thing to keep in mind with the graphics is that they get separated into 2 categories: the presentation/art style and the actual performance. In the first one, this game is quite stunning with great lighting, amazing art design and impressive character models. Sure the level design is incredibly repetitive, subscribing to that "everywhere else is a mess and untraverseable except this one path" thing. But it's in the second category where the game falters since there's some pop up and things that seem to disappear/reappear, clipping, characters doing that weird glitch when they get stuck, some slowdown and the game even froze momentarily and in 2 cases for me personally, froze entirely and needed a restart. Game could've used a lot more polish and hopefully a future patch will correct it, especially the freezing bug.Sound/Music: Let's face it, the Star Wars films have some of the best music ever in a film. The ironic problem is that game developers seem to think so too so the score for the videogames barely deviates from it. We have all the familiar themes and more than once you'll hear a tune you know from the movie. That being said, the game is amazing to hear with the aforementioned voice acting too and this time, there's no glitches.Gameplay: Here's the proverbial backbreaking straw. Remember that one sentence I said about game developers using a cool idea because it's cool as opposed to a fun one? This game is similar and many aspects of the game just don't make sense even for people who don't even create games for a living. A character can't do a thing when they're hit unless left alone for awhile which is aggravating having to feel the full combo from the enemy as opposed to, I don't know, moving to the side and dodging? Then there's the Force Grab where you can grab enemies and sending them flying or grab things and send them flying to enemies. Believe me, it's fun to launch a huge block and smack em in their evil faces but the problem is that there's no real targeting tactic and frequently you'll grab some useful pipe as opposed to the enemy and also it's hard to target what you want to actually throw it at and it becomes kind of like playing pool where you have to line up your shot and hope it hits.The combat though is fun and the combos aren't that complex in moves like Heavenly Sword or Devil May Cry though there is some repetition and some moves I couldn't even activate making me just stick to tried-and-true techniques. But all that gets knocked out of the way when you lift an enemy into the air and fire your lightsaber and impale the jerk or having him thrown off a really high ledge. Being evil has never been this much fun and with the option to buy more combos or better stats and even your costume and lightsaber color, there's a lot of customization available.Now for the epitome of the bad part that's included because it's cool: the Star Destroyer. As the trailers showed, we can rip one of these bad boys right from the sky and make the sucker crash only the hugeness of this event seems to warrant a beyond-maddening sequence where you have a rate of turn that's too slow and a long distance you have to pull it to before it actually crashes. Oh and did I mention you're being shot at by multiple TIE Fighters that can't seem to be targeted for longer than a second? Very frequently you'll finally get your Star Destroyer lined up to be pulled down only the Fighters show up and shoot your *** up, making you having to deal with them lest you die and start over...oh yeah and the ship turns back to its original position making you having to slowly turn it back and then pulling it. This is the kind of sequence that when you replay it, it increases the dread and you'll find yourself going "oh no, THAT part is coming up."Now if it sounds like I'm being incredibly negative towards the game, sorry. I have to admit I liked it and more than once I've thought of actually purchasing the game despite the huge amount of flaws that plague the game. But here's the thing: the presentation, the story, the music and not to mention just the sheer fun of laying the smackdown with your lightsaber is too hard to resist. Is it a masterpiece? Heh, far from it but for every thing it does wrong, I forgive it because it's doing something I like. Will you like it as much? Doubt it but it doesn't hurt to try. Hey, even critically acclaimed games like Grand Theft Auto IV and Halo 3 have their detractors, maybe flawed games like this can have their fans too.

summary: The complete version of Resident Evil 5
reviewText: **As a special side note please be aware that ONLY the PlayStation 3 version includes all the content on 1 disc, the 360 version of Gold Edition comes with a download voucher, which requires High speed internet access and a Xbox Live account to download the extra content without those you can not access the extra content on Xbox 360**This game is essentially a HD version of RE4 with a co-op (2 player) online or AI (computer controlled) partner. This game is best with another player controlling Sheva but its perfectly fine as a single player game too. This Gold Edition re-release includes the following:Lost in Nightmares bonus missionDesperate Escape bonus missionMercenaries Reunion battle gameBarry Burton, Rebecca Chambers and Excella Gionne as playable characters in Mercenaries Reunion mode.4 new costumes (2 for Sheva and 2 for Chris)Extra in game figures to collectOnline player vs player Versus mode.Overall this is a very good deal for those that passed on the original release.

description: Comfortable wired rubber earhook, Next Gen Bluetooth chipset and a noise cancelling speaker enabling you to focus on your game in comfort. Like all of our products, the EX-03 follows one important rule: form follows function, the body is designed with with comfort as a priority, Next Gen Bluetooth Chipset has been utilized for clarity of voice and improved over standard with a sound chamber design producing a fuller sound overall. Military rubber coated styling together with intuitive controls and easy pairing complete the EX-03.
reviewText: This is a big earpiece.  I don't mean a bit on the large size.  I mean designed to be comfortable for Sasquatch.  When I hang it from my ear, the ear bud lands on my earring.  I'm 5' 5", but I feel like an elf when I'm wearing it, and an elf trying rock camouflage-colored earpieces is just a bad idea.  So after I detangled the pretend military equipment from my hot pink beaded hoops (looked like Rambo meets Rainbow Bright) I tried adjusting it.  It doesn't adjust.  It is strictly one size fits giants.The sound quality is spotty at times, but overall decent.  If you're one of those huge guys who can't walk into a doorway without ducking, this might be perfect for you. If you're an orc, these are the earbuds you're looking for.

description: Godzilla Unleashed - Everyone's favorite monster returns in a completely redesigned and updated massively destructive brawler! Play Godzilla as never before with non-linear story paths and all new Toho monsters.
summary: True Godzilla fans may appreciate it more
reviewText: Overall, this is not really a bad game. The graphics are very nice. Sharp, crisp, clean and clear. However, if you are looking at this game to have a deep and engaging story mode... then you may want to look for a different game. The story mode, at least to me, was very flat and uninteresting.I think the appeal of this game will be in two areas.1 - Hard core Godzilla fans will no doubt love the inclusion of all the different monsters and unlockables. Personally, being only a casual Goddzilla fan, many of those things are no doubt lost on me. I only recognize a handful of monsters so that draw for me is lessened.2 - the multi-player aspect has the feel of being a blast. Up to four people can have an all out brawl, or destroy as many buildings as you can. Kind of akin to the old Rampage video game.One thing that frustrated me was the length of the battles. Most "traditional" fighters have a minute to a minute and a half length on 'rounds'. Not so here. You can easily hit the five minute mark for one battle, which at times, makes you lose interest in the battle and the game.While there are some fun aspects to the game, the controls (especially later in the game) become hampering and frustrating. As a multi player it is fun, as a single player... not so much. I don't think I would pay full price for it, probably best to hold off until you see it in the bargin bin.

summary: Somewhat fun, but gets old quick
reviewText: I lasted a total of maybe 5 hours before I had the base game beat. I then let my daughter have her fun with it, and she lost interest after not even an hour. Since then, it has been collecting dust in our library. Although it is somewhat fun for a while, this game should've been released with a 19.99 price tag.
